mid.context: You have basics but need to unify customer identity and handle cookie limitations
quick_wins: Implement server-side tracking for key conversion events
Set up cross-domain tracking if you have multiple domains
Create a data layer documentation for your team
Audit for tracking gaps with a tool like ObservePoint or manual QA

recommended_tools.name: Segment
recommended_tools.fit: Brands wanting unified tracking and identity resolution
recommended_tools.note: Industry standard CDP. Centralizes tracking, fans out to destinations.

recommended_tools.name: RudderStack
recommended_tools.fit: More technical teams wanting CDP on own infrastructure
recommended_tools.note: Open-source alternative to Segment. Lower cost at scale.

recommended_tools.name: Littledata
recommended_tools.fit: Shopify stores wanting server-side and GA4 improvements
recommended_tools.note: Automated Shopify tracking fixes. Good alternative to Elevar.

mid.diy_alternative: Build your own server-side tracking with Cloudflare Workers or AWS Lambda. Technical but gives full control. Open-source options like Snowplow are available.

mid.context: You have attribution but need validation through incrementality testing
quick_wins: Run your first geo-holdout test on your highest-spend channel
Compare platform-reported ROAS to blended ROAS (total revenue / total spend)
Calculate platform conversion overlap, how much are they all claiming the same sales?
Build a channel efficiency dashboard that tracks CAC trend over time

recommended_tools.name: Measured
recommended_tools.fit: Brands wanting rigorous incrementality measurement
recommended_tools.note: Specialized in incrementality. Run proper experiments at scale.

recommended_tools.name: Recast
recommended_tools.fit: Brands $10M+ spend wanting MMM for budget allocation
recommended_tools.note: Modern MMM. Bayesian approach with faster results than traditional MMM.

recommended_tools.name: Liftsight
recommended_tools.fit: Mid-market brands wanting incrementality without enterprise pricing
recommended_tools.note: Geo-lift and incrementality testing platform. More accessible pricing.

mid.diy_alternative: Run manual geo-holdout tests. Pick 2 or 3 states, pause ads for 2 or 3 weeks, measure sales delta vs control states. Simple but effective. Google has detailed geo-experiment guides.

recommended_tools.name: GA4 (Data-driven attribution) + BigQuery export
recommended_tools.fit: Use GA4's attribution + raw event export to BigQuery to reconcile paths vs orders and spot mis-credit.
recommended_tools.note: Primitive but powerful: paths + UTMs + order truth. This replaces entry-level attribution dashboards.

recommended_tools.name: UTM Governance + Attribution Spreadsheet
recommended_tools.fit: A strict UTM taxonomy + a weekly sheet that compares platform claims vs actual orders/revenue.
recommended_tools.note: This is the first reality check layer before any fancy tooling.

recommended_tools.name: Simple MTA in Python (Markov / heuristics)
recommended_tools.fit: Build a basic multi-touch model from GA4 paths (Markov removal effect or rule-based weighting).
recommended_tools.note: Good for directional channel contribution when you can't trust platform-reported conversions.

recommended_tools.name: GeoLift (open-source)
recommended_tools.fit: Run geo holdout experiments with principled inference, DIY alternative to geo-testing platforms.
recommended_tools.note: Designed specifically for geo experiments: market selection + lift estimation.

recommended_tools.name: CausalImpact
recommended_tools.fit: Estimate lift from interventions using Bayesian structural time series when full randomization is hard.
recommended_tools.note: Useful for pauses, shocks, and pre/post with controls.

recommended_tools.name: PyMC (Bayesian MMM engine)
recommended_tools.fit: Build MMM in-house with real uncertainty, priors, adstock, saturation, and hierarchical pooling.
recommended_tools.note: This is the primitive replacement for modern MMM vendors.

recommended_tools.name: Meridian (open-source)
recommended_tools.fit: Standardize MMM runs + calibration workflow for a mature measurement program.
recommended_tools.note: Use as the system around MMM (repeatability + governance).

recommended_tools.name: Robyn (open-source)
recommended_tools.fit: Run frequent MMM refreshes and scenario planning quickly, good for ongoing optimization cycles.
recommended_tools.note: Works well as a high-velocity MMM baseline in mature stacks.

recommended_tools.name: Budget optimization (SciPy / constrained optimization) on MMM posteriors
recommended_tools.fit: Automate budget recommendations using constrained optimization (min/max spend, CAC targets, channel caps).
recommended_tools.note: This is the primitive replacement for automated budget reallocation products.

mid.context: You have dashboards but need better self-service and consistency
quick_wins: Create a data dictionary documenting all metrics and their definitions
Set up scheduled Slack or email alerts for key metric anomalies
Train 3 to 5 power users to answer their own questions in dashboards
Audit existing dashboards, remove duplicates and unused reports

recommended_tools.name: Metabase
recommended_tools.fit: Technical teams wanting free self-service BI
recommended_tools.note: Open-source BI. Self-hostable. Good balance of ease and power.

recommended_tools.name: Hex
recommended_tools.fit: Data teams wanting notebook and dashboard hybrid
recommended_tools.note: Modern analytics notebook. Great for analysis that becomes dashboards.

recommended_tools.name: Omni
recommended_tools.fit: Teams wanting Looker-like semantic layer without Looker complexity
recommended_tools.note: Modern BI with modeling layer. Good for consistent metrics.

mid.diy_alternative: Define metrics in dbt and surface them through any BI tool. This metrics layer approach ensures consistency regardless of which dashboard someone uses.

mid.context: You run tests but need to scale velocity and systematize learnings
quick_wins: Create a testing calendar with planned experiments
Build a learning repository documenting all past tests
Calculate your current testing velocity (tests per month)
Identify testing coverage gaps (which areas are not being tested?)

recommended_tools.name: Optimizely
recommended_tools.fit: Brands wanting enterprise-grade experimentation
recommended_tools.note: Industry leader. Feature flags, web, and full-stack testing.

recommended_tools.name: AB Tasty
recommended_tools.fit: Mid-market brands wanting solid testing and personalization
recommended_tools.note: Good balance of capability and complexity. Strong in Europe.

recommended_tools.name: Statsig
recommended_tools.fit: Technical teams wanting modern, developer-friendly experimentation
recommended_tools.note: Built for product teams. Feature flags and experiments. Free tier available.

mid.diy_alternative: Build internal experimentation framework with feature flags (LaunchDarkly or open-source Unleash) and statistical analysis in Python or R. Gives full control.

mid.context: You have flows but need better segmentation and lifecycle stage management
quick_wins: Implement RFM segmentation (Recency, Frequency, Monetary)
Create lifecycle stage definitions (new, active, at-risk, churned)
Build a VIP program or high-value customer treatment
Set up replenishment triggers for consumable products

recommended_tools.name: Retention.com
recommended_tools.fit: Brands wanting to identify anonymous site visitors for email
recommended_tools.note: Identify anonymous visitors. Significantly expands email capture.

recommended_tools.name: Attentive
recommended_tools.fit: Brands wanting sophisticated SMS program
recommended_tools.note: Premium SMS platform. Strong for brands investing heavily in SMS.

recommended_tools.name: Yotpo
recommended_tools.fit: Brands wanting loyalty program and reviews in one platform
recommended_tools.note: Combined loyalty, reviews, SMS. Good for consolidation.

mid.diy_alternative: Build RFM segmentation in your warehouse and sync to Klaviyo via their API. Calculate churn probability with simple rules (no purchase in X days equals at-risk).

mid.context: You have infrastructure but need to improve reliability, documentation, and coverage
quick_wins: Add data quality tests (nulls, duplicates, freshness checks)
Document your data models and transformations
Set up pipeline failure alerts
Connect remaining data sources to close gaps

recommended_tools.name: dbt
recommended_tools.fit: Everyone with a warehouse, industry standard
recommended_tools.note: SQL-based transformation. Open-source core. Essential for data quality.

recommended_tools.name: Snowflake
recommended_tools.fit: Growing brands needing scalable, separated compute
recommended_tools.note: Modern warehouse. Scales well. Excellent for analytics workloads.

recommended_tools.name: Census
recommended_tools.fit: Teams wanting to sync warehouse data to operational tools
recommended_tools.note: Push data from warehouse to Klaviyo, Salesforce, etc. Closes the loop.

mid.diy_alternative: Implement dbt with built-in testing and documentation. It is free and transforms how you manage data quality. Invest time here before buying more tools.
